content: started slip_stitch into first slip_stitch chain 1 then work 1 single_crochet in each chain around slip_stitch into first single_crochet finish off 11 8 photos 8 1 flat ribbon a row a1 b row a3 c row a5 showing two single_crochet d ready to add flower b in the same petal figure 4 section 5 1 wrap around the first flower a row b1 b row b3 c row b5 showing all petals of flower a with two slip stitches each figure 5 section 5 2 add the second flower and close the starting edge starting flower b and finishing flower a 12 a row b6 b row b8 c ready to add flower c figure 6 section 5 2 add the second flower and close the starting edge merging the starting edge of the vine a row c1 b row c2 c row c4 where we finish d row c6 where the vine filling up the old flower joins itself figure 7 section 5 3 add the third flower to memorize the procedure note that once we add the next flower there are three more row where we finish up the last flower we stitch into the petals of the old flower twice and then we attach to the vine 13 figure 8 section 5 3 add the third flower to memorize the procedure this is an important configuration to look out for two petals left with one slip_stitch each the next row will incorporate a new flower a readytostartrowd1 onepetal b row d2 note there are now 7 double_crochet c row d3 joining the final flower worked into once four petals worked along the vine note the unworked double crochets into twice one petal untouched from row d2 figure 9 section 5 5 add the last two flowers 14 figure 10 section 5 6 finish wrapping around the final flower we ve worked into each petal of the final flower twice so the next row will be row e1 a row e1 b rowe2 withanarrowindicating c row e3 the unworked double_crochet that will be slipped into on the next row figure 11 section 5 6 finish wrapping around the final flower 15 8 2 looped variant a row a1 optional marker not pictured b row a3 ◦ ◦ c row a5 d before adding flower b ◦ figure 12 section 6 1 start
